data.title: Cheat Sheet
data.description: Use this cheat sheet to brush up on your Linux commands and for all those Linux commands you can't quite remember!

userActivity.Value: /lib - "c" libraries used by programs and kernel
/usr - user programs and utilities (binaries, docs, libraries, include files, etc.)
/bin - OS essential binaries (ls, cp, mv, etc.)
/etc - system configuration files, includes startup scripts
/mnt - mount point for external file systems
/var - variable data (mail and printer spools, log files, lock files, etc.)

userActivity.Value:
yum update
yum install yum-utils
yum-config-manager --add-repo=https://packages.microsoft.com/config/fedora/38/prod.repo
rpm --import http://packages.microsoft.com/keys/microsoft.asc
yum install mdatp
yum install pcre

yum update
yum install yum-utils
yum-config-manager --add-repo=https://packages.microsoft.com/config/rhel/8/prod.repo
rpm --import http://packages.microsoft.com/keys/microsoft.asc
yum install mdatp

yum update
yum install puppet-agent
yum install yum-utils
rpm -U http://yum.puppet.com/puppet6-release-el-9.noarch.rpm
yum install puppet-agent
puppet agent -t

#On Puppet server
/opt/puppetlabs/bin/puppetserver ca sign --all

zypper update
rpm --import http://packages.microsoft.com/keys/microsoft.asc
zypper install mdatp

apt-get install update
apt-get install libplist-utils
apt-get install curl
curl -o microsoft.list https://packages.microsoft.com/config/ubuntu/20.04/prod.list
mv ./microsoft.list /etc/apt/sources.list.d/microsoft-prod.list
apt-get install gpg
curl -sSL https://packages.microsoft.com/keys/microsoft.asc | gpg --dearmor | sudo tee /etc/apt/trusted.gpg.d/microsoft.gpg > /dev/null
apt-get install apt-transport-https
apt-get update
apt-get install mdatp

userActivity.Value: Using the stat command we can check the permissions of the directories and files.
The 'Access' should show permissions matching: (0755/drwxr-xr-x) If they do not match, update them with the below commands

data.title: System Load Monitoring
data.description: Monitor the system load to understand the demand on system resources.

userActivity.Value: uptime  gives a one line display of the following information.  The current time, how long the system has been running, how many users are currently logged on, and the system load  averages for the past 1, 5, and 15 minutes.

backgroundActivity.Value: The output shows the current system load averages for the past 1, 5, and 15 minutes.

userActivity.Value: free  displays  the  total  amount of free and used physical and swap memory in the system, as well as the buffers and caches used by the kernel.

backgroundActivity.Value: The output shows the total, used, and free memory in megabytes.

total        used        free      shared  buff/cache   available
Mem:           1912         461         973           8         477        1230
Swap:             0           0           0

userActivity.Value: `free` gets its information from the /proc/meminfo file. You can view /proc/meminfor more detailed information.

userActivity.Value: df displays the amount of disk space available on the file system containing each file name argument.  If no file  name  is  given,  the space  available  on  all  currently mounted file systems is shown.
`-h` option is used to display the output in human readable format.

userActivity.Value: nload is a console application which monitors network traffic and bandwidth usage in real time. It visualizes the in and outgoing traffic using two graphs and provides additional info like the total amount of transfered data and min/max network usage.

backgroundActivity.Value: The output shows the current network usage for each interface.

data.title: Envrionment Setup
data.description: Getting the environment ready for MDE for Linux on Centos

userActivity.Value: Update packages using the yum package manager
Each Linux distrobution has a different package manager. For example, Ubuntu uses apt-get, while Centos uses yum.
Add the Microsoft repo to isntall MDE

backgroundActivity.Value: The RPM package repository will be added to the system. This will allow you to install MDE using yum.
The output below shows the RPM package being added to the system.

userActivity.Value: We can check the respoiory list to see if the Microsoft repo has been added

data.title: Diagnostics
data.description: Troubleshoot MDE product issues and collect diagnostics

userActivity.Value: This command provides diagnostic tests for Microsoft Defender for Endpoint.

backgroundActivity.Value: There are several options to create diagnostic data and upload it to Microsoft.

antivirus-engine-pool-content         Monitor the content for all antivirus engine core pools content
  create                                Generate support log
  real-time-protection-statistics       Display real-time protection resource usage statistics
  event-provider-statistics             Display event provider internal statistics
  behavior-monitoring-statistics        Display behavior monitoring resource usage statistics
  hot-event-sources                     Monitor hot event sources (preview feature)
  ebpf-statistics                       Display ebpf internal statistics
  upload                                Generate and submit support log to Microsoft

userActivity.Value: This command checks the behavior monitoring statistics for Microsoft Defender for Endpoint.
This command checks the hot event sources for Microsoft Defender for Endpoint.
We can run this command for both files and executables. It will generate a json file in the current directory with the number of events that occurred while the command ran.
The command will run indefinitely until you stop it with CTRL+C.

backgroundActivity.Value: Sample Output from 'sudo mdatp diagnostic hot-event-sources files'

=========== Hot Event Sources ===========
Top 0 hot event sources. Total Events: 0 Time: 5s. Throughput: 0events/sec
count  file path
Press CTRL+C to stop the command when you have enough data.
We can now view the output from the generated .json file. The file will be named 'hot_event_sources_<GUID>.json'.
This example ran for 5 seconds and observed no events.
A large number of events may indicate a performance issue.

data.title: RHEL iptables
data.description: Use the guide to troubleshoot issues with MDE connectivity to the Microsoft cloud service endpoints. We will use iptables to block and then allow outbound traffic to the MDE endpoints so we can see what errors and logs occur.

data.title: Check iptables rules
data.description: Allow MDE to communicate with the Microsoft cloud service endpoints.

backgroundActivity.Value: The output shows the current iptables rules. The -S option is used to list the rules in a format that can be used as input to iptables-restore.

-P INPUT ACCEPT
-P FORWARD ACCEPT
-P OUTPUT ACCEPT
The above output shows that the default policy for the INPUT, FORWARD and OUTPUT chains is ACCEPT.

userActivity.Value: Test outbound connection with curl works successfully

backgroundActivity.Value:
301 Moved

The document has moved here.

userActivity.Value: sudo iptables -A OUTPUT -p tcp -m multiport --dport 80,443 -j REJECT

backgroundActivity.Value: Our iptables rule was applied, we can check by viewing the rules again.

Chain INPUT (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination

Chain FORWARD (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination

Chain OUTPUT (policy ACCEPT)
target     prot opt source               destination
REJECT     tcp  --  anywhere             anywhere             multiport dports http,https reject-with icmp-port-unreachable
Any subsequent curl commands on port 80 and 443 will fail.

userActivity.Value: Test outbound connection with curl is blocked successfully

backgroundActivity.Value: curl: (28) Failed to connect to google.com port 80: Connection timed out
The above output shows that the connection timed out, which means the outbound traffic was blocked.

data.title: Connectivity Test
data.description: Check MDATP connectivity to the Microsoft cloud service endpoints.

userActivity.Value: Check MDATP connectivity to the Microsoft cloud service endpoints.
mdatp has a built-in connectivity test that can be used to check connectivity to the Microsoft cloud service endpoints.
The connectivity test will take a few minutes to complete.

backgroundActivity.Value:

userActivity.Value: Allow outbound traffic to MDE endpoints
From our test above we can see which endpoints are blocked.

You should always refer to the official documentation for the latest list of endpoints. https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/microsoft-365/security/defender-endpoint/microsoft-defender-endpoint-linux?view=o365-worldwide#network-connections
For the purpose of this lab we will allow only the endpoints identified in the previous step.
Allow outbound traffic to the Microsoft cloud service endpoints.
This is for demonstration purposes only. Using domain/host name in iptables rules is not recommended. You should always use IP addresses.

When iptables applies to rule above  it evaluates the domain name and resolves it to an IP address. If the IP address changes, the rule will no longer work. You will need to update the rule with the new IP address.
If we perform multiple nslookups against nf.smartscreen.microsoft.com we can see that the IP address changes.

Non-authoritative answer:
nf.smartscreen.microsoft.com    canonical name = wd-prod-ss.trafficmanager.net.
wd-prod-ss.trafficmanager.net   canonical name = wd-prod-ss-us-east-2-fe.eastus.cloudapp.azure.com.
Name:   wd-prod-ss-us-east-2-fe.eastus.cloudapp.azure.com
Address: 20.246.247.192

wd-prod-ss.trafficmanager.net   canonical name = wd-prod-ss-us-northcentral-2-fe.northcentralus.cloudapp.azure.com.
Name:   wd-prod-ss-us-northcentral-2-fe.northcentralus.cloudapp.azure.com
Address: 52.159.118.63

userActivity.Value: Now that we have allowed outbound traffic to the Microsoft cloud service endpoints, we can run the connectivity test again.
The connectivity test may take a few minutes to complete.

backgroundActivity.Value:
Testing connection with https://nf.smartscreen.microsoft.com/api/network/mac ... [ERROR]
        ["(request #182)","Failed to connect to any resolved endpoint"]
        Unknown error -1 (error code -1)

Most of our endpoints succed while some do not. This is because the IP address for those endpoints have changed since we added them to our iptables rule.
For production environments it's best to use a proxy or firewall that can allow outbound traffic to the Microsoft cloud service URL endpoints.

data.title: View recommendations
data.description: View recommendations from the Microsoft 365 Defender portal

userActivity.Value: Navigate to https://security.microsoft.com/security-recommendations and review the recommendations for your environment.

backgroundActivity.Value: What is the security portal doing?
The Microsoft 365 Defender portal is analyzing your environment and providing recommendations based on the security posture of your environment.

userActivity.Value: In this scenario we are reviewing teh Update Oracle Kernel-uek for Linux

backgroundActivity.Value: What's does the portal show us?
The portal advises us to update the kerel, it shows the list of exposed/installed devices, and any associated CVEs related to this vulnerability.
We can also see the list of CVEs associated with this vulnerability.

data.title: Update the kernel
data.description: Update the kernel on the Oracle Linux server

userActivity.Value: One method is to update the kernel using uptrack. This allows us to update the kernel without rebooting the server.

backgroundActivity.Value: The output shows the kernel being updated. It displays CVE that are being addressed, and the kernel version being installed.

userActivity.Value: Another method is to use dnf upgrade.
Reboot the server to complete the kernel update.

data.title: Check the Security Portal
data.description: Check the Microsoft 365 Defender portal for updates

userActivity.Value: Navigate back to the Microsoft 365 Defender portal and review the recommendations.
The portal will take some time to update depending on how often the agent reports back to the MDE service.

backgroundActivity.Value: What's does the portal show us?
The portal shows that the Oracle Kernel has been updated, and the CVEs have been addressed.
